sen.j: 貴船神社（きふねじんじゃ、きぶねじんじゃ）
sen.e: Kifune-jinja Shrine (also known as Kibune-jinja Shrine).
Kifune-jinja Shrine (also known as Kibune-jinja Shrine).
Kifune-jinja Shrine (also known as Kibune-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 京都市左京区にある神社。
sen.e: A Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
A Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
A Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 本稿で詳述。
sen.e: Described in this article.
Described in this article.
Described in this article.

sen.j: 同神社のより勧請を受けた各地の神社。
sen.e: Also the name of shrines throughout Japan that have received the divided tutelary deity of the above shrine.
Also the name of shrines throughout Japan that have received the divided tutelary deity of the above shrine.

sen.j: 各地の貴船神社の項を参照。
sen.e: Please refer to the Kifune-jinja Shrines for each area.
Please refer to the Kifune-jinja Shrines for each area.

sen.j: 貴船神社 (真鶴町) - 神奈川県真鶴町にある神社。
sen.e: Kifune-jinja Temple (Manazuru Town): A Shinto shrine located in Manazuru Town, Kanagawa Prefecture.
Kifune-jinja Temple (Manazuru Town): A Shinto shrine located in Manazuru Town, Kanagawa Prefecture.
Kifune-jinja Shrine (Manazuru Town): A Shinto shrine located in Manazuru Town, Kanagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 貴宮（きのみや）大明神から改称したもので、貴船神社から勧請されたものではない。
sen.e: Did not receive the divided tutelary deity from Mibune-jinja Shrine but was renamed from Kinomiya Daimyojin Shrine.
Did not receive the divided tutelary deity from Mibune-jinja Shrine but was renamed from Kinomiya Daimyojin Shrine.
Did not receive the divided tutelary deity from Kifune-jinja Shrine but was renamed from Kinomiya Daimyojin Shrine.

sen.j: 貴船神社（きふねじんじゃ）は、京都市左京区にある神社である。
sen.e: Kifune-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kifune-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kifune-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大社）、二十二社の一社で、旧社格は官幣中社。
sen.e: The Register of Deities of the Engishiki classifies it as a Myojin Taisha, it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and it was ranked as a Kanpei Chusha under the old system of shrine classifications.
The Register of Deities of the Engishiki classifies it as a Myojin Taisha, it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and it was ranked as a Kanpei Chusha under the old system of shrine classifications.

The Register of Deities of the Engishiki classifies it as a Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha), it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and it was ranked as a Kanpei Chusha under the old system of shrine classifications.
sen.cmt: 「式内社」を訳出し、"a Shikinaisha (Myojin Taisha)"としました。

sen.j: 日本全国に約450社ある貴船神社の総本社である。
sen.e: It is the head shrine of the approximately 450 Kifune-jinja Shrines throughout Japan.
It is the head shrine of the approximately 450 Kifune-jinja Shrines throughout Japan.
It is the head shrine of the approximately 450 Kifune-jinja Shrines throughout Japan.

tit.cmt: 表記を他の記事と統一

sen.j: 水神である淤加美神（たかおかみのかみ）を祀り、古代の祈雨八十五座の一座とされるなど、古くから祈雨の神として信仰された。
sen.e: Kifune-jinja Shrine enshrines the water god Takaokami-no Kami and, as one of the eighty-five ancient shrines of rainmaking rites, the deity has long been worshipped by those praying for rain.
Kifune-jinja Shrine enshrines the water god Takaokami-no Kami and, as one of the eighty-five ancient shrines of rainmaking rites, the deity has long been worshipped by those praying for rain.
Kifune-jinja Shrine enshrines the water god Takaokami no Kami and, as one of the eighty-five ancient shrines of rainmaking rites, the deity has long been worshipped by those praying for rain.
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、Takaokami no Kamiとしました。

sen.j: 古来より、晴れを願うときには白馬が、雨を願うときには黒馬が奉納されたが、実際の馬に代わって木の板に描いた馬が奉納されたこともあり、このことから絵馬が発祥したとも言われる。
sen.e: Since ancient times, a white horse has been offered to pray for fine weather and a black horse to pray for rain, but an image of a horse painted onto a wooden board may also be offered, which led to the creation of ema tablets.

Since ancient times, a white horse has been offered to pray for fine weather and a black horse to pray for rain, but an image of a horse painted onto a wooden board may also be offered, which led to the creation of ema tablets.

Since ancient times, a white horse has been offered to pray for fine weather and a black horse to pray for rain, but an image of a horse painted onto a wooden board may also be offered, which led to the creation of ema tablets.

sen.j: また、縁結びの神としての信仰もあり、小説や漫画の陰陽師による人気もあり、若いカップルや女性で賑わっている。
sen.e: He is also worshipped as the god of marriage so is popular with fortune tellers in novels and comics and draws many young couples and women.
He is also worshipped as the god of marriage so is popular with fortune tellers in novels and comics and draws many young couples and women.
He is also worshipped as the god of marriage so is popular with fortune tellers in novels and comics and draws many young couples and women.

sen.j: その一方で縁切りの神、呪咀神としても信仰されており、丑の刻参りでも有名である。
sen.e: On the other hand, he is believed to be the god of separation and the god of curses and the shrine is famous for the practice of "Ushi No Koku Mairi" (placing a curse on someone by nailing a doll representing them to a tree between the hours of 1am and 3am).

On the other hand, he is believed to be the god of separation and the god of curses and the shrine is famous for the practice of "Ushi No Koku Mairi" (placing a curse on someone by nailing a doll representing them to a tree between the hours of 1am and 3am).

On the other hand, he is believed to be the god of separation and the god of curses and the shrine is famous for the practice of "Ushi No Koku Mairi" (placing a curse on someone by nailing a doll representing them to a tree between the hours of 1am and 3am).

sen.j: 付近は京都でも有名な紅葉の名所のひとつである。
sen.e: Even within Kyoto, the vicinity of the shrine is particularly famous for its beautiful autumn leaves.
Even within Kyoto, the vicinity of the shrine is particularly famous for its beautiful autumn leaves.
Even within Kyoto, the vicinity of the shrine is particularly famous for its beautiful autumn leaves.

sen.j: 創建の年代は不詳であるが、社伝では反正天皇の時代の創建としている。
sen.e: It is not known with certainty when the shrine was founded but, according to shrine legend, it was founded during the reign of Emperor Hanzei.
It is not known with certainty when the shrine was founded but, according to shrine legend, it was founded during the reign of Emperor Hanzei.
It is not known with certainty when the shrine was founded but, according to shrine legend, it was founded during the reign of Emperor Hanzei.

sen.j: 社伝によれば、神武天皇の母であるタマヨリビメが、黄色い船に乗って淀川・鴨川 (淀川水系)・貴船川を遡って当地に上陸し、水神を祭ったのに始まると伝えている。
sen.e: The shrine legend also tells the shrine originated when Tamayori-bime, the mother of Emperor Jinmu, sailed up the Yado-gawa/Kamo-gawa river system and Kifune-gawa River where she disembarked at the site of the shine and enshrined the water god.

The shrine legend also tells the shrine originated when Tamayori-bime, the mother of Emperor Jinmu, sailed up the Yado-gawa/Kamo-gawa river system and Kifune-gawa River where she disembarked at the site of the shine and enshrined the water god.

The shrine legend also tells the shrine originated when Tamayoribime, the mother of Emperor Jinmu, sailed up the Yodo-gawa River, Kamo-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system), and Kifune-gawa River where she disembarked at the site of the shine and enshrined the water god.
sen.cmt: Tamayori-bime→Tamayoribime、Yado-gawa→Yodo-gawaに修正、「淀川・鴨川 (淀川水系)・貴船川」→"Yodo-gawa River, Kamo-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system), and Kifune-gawa River"としました。

sen.j: 社名の由来は「黄船」によるものとし、奥宮境内にある「御船型石」が、玉依姫命が乗ってきた船が小石に覆われたものと伝える。
sen.e: It is believed that the shrine's name is derived from the word 'kifune' (lit. Yellow Boat) and it is said that the "Mifunegata-ishi" pebbles in the precinct of the rear shrine cover the boat on which Tamayorihime-no Mikoto arrived.

It is believed that the shrine's name is derived from the word 'kifune' (lit. Yellow Boat) and it is said that the "Mifunegata-ishi" pebbles in the precinct of the rear shrine cover the boat on which Tamayorihime-no Mikoto arrived.

It is believed that the shrine's name is derived from the word 'kifune' (lit. Yellow Boat) and it is said that the 'Mifunegata-ishi' pebbles in the precincts of the rear shrine cover the boat on which Tamayoribime no Mikoto arrived.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、precinct→precinctsとしました。前出の表記に合わせ、Tamayorihime→Tamayorbimeとし、後のハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: 「気の産まれる根源」が転じて「気生根」になったともいう。
sen.e: It is also suggested that the name derives from the phrase 'Ki no umareru kigen' (lit. the source of life energy) being abbreviated to 'kibune'.
It is also suggested that the name derives from the phrase 'Ki no umareru kigen' (lit. the source of life energy) being abbreviated to 'kibune'.
It is also suggested that the name derives from the phrase 'Ki no umareru kigen' (lit. the source of life energy) being abbreviated to 'kibune'.

sen.j: 白鳳6年（666年？）に、最も古い社殿造替えの記録がある。
sen.e: The oldest remodeling of a Shinto shrine main sanctuary is recorded to have taken place circa 666.
The oldest remodeling of a Shinto shrine main sanctuary is recorded to have taken place circa 666.
The oldest remodeling of a Shinto shrine main sanctuary is recorded to have taken place circa 666.

sen.j: 日本後紀に、延暦15年（796年）、東寺の造営の任に当たっていた藤原伊勢人の夢に貴船神社の神が現れ、鞍馬寺を建立するよう託宣したと記されている。
sen.e: The text 'Nihon Koki' records that the kami of Kifune-jinja Shrine appeared to FUJIWARA no Iseto, who was charged with the construction of To-ji Temple, in a dream and commanded him to establish Kurama-dera Temple.

The text 'Nihon Koki' records that the kami of Kifune-jinja Shrine appeared to FUJIWARA no Iseto, who was charged with the construction of To-ji Temple, in a dream and commanded him to establish Kurama-dera Temple.

The text Nihon Koki (Later Chronicle of Japan) records that the kami of Kifune-jinja Shrine appeared to FUJIWARA no Iseto, who was charged with the construction of To-ji Temple, in a dream and commanded him to establish Kurama-dera Temple in 796.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ'Nihon Koki'のクォーテーションをとり、補足を追加しました。年号補足

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には「山城国愛宕郡 貴布禰神社」として記載され、名神大社に列している。
sen.e: The Engi Shinmyo Cho (Register of Deities of the Engishiki) lists the shrine as "Kifune-jinja Shrine in Atago County, Yamashiro Province" and classifies it as a Myojin Taisha.
The Engi Shinmyo Cho (Register of Deities of the Engishiki) lists the shrine as "Kifune-jinja Shrine in Atago County, Yamashiro Province" and classifies it as a Myojin Taisha.
The Engishiki Jinmyocho (Register of Deities of the Engishiki) lists the shrine as 'Kifune-jinja Shrine in Atago County, Yamashiro Province' and classifies it as a Myojin Taisha.
sen.cmt: Engi Shinmyo Cho→Engishiki Jinmyochoに修正、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 後に二十二社の一社とされ、保延6年（1140年）に最高位の正一位の神階を授けられている。
sen.e: In addition, it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines and was granted the rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) in 1140.
In addition, it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines and was granted the rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) in 1140.
In addition, it is one of the Twenty-Two Shrines and was granted the rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) in 1140.

sen.j: 永承元年（1046年）7月、出水により社殿が流出し、天喜3年（1055年）、現在の本宮の地に社殿を再建・遷座して、元の鎮座地は奥宮とした。
sen.e: In July 1046, it was swept away in a flood and the main sanctuary was reconstructed on the current site of the main shrine in 1055 and the previous place of enshrinement was designated as the rear shrine.

In July 1046, it was swept away in a flood and the main sanctuary was reconstructed on the current site of the main shrine in 1055 and the previous place of enshrinement was designated as the rear shrine.

In July 1046, it was swept away in a flood and the main sanctuary was reconstructed on the current site of the main shrine in 1055 and the previous place of enshrinement was designated as the rear shrine.

sen.j: 当社は長らく賀茂別雷神社（上賀茂神社）の摂社とされてきたが、これは天喜3年の社殿再建が契起となっているとする説がある。
sen.e: It had long been considered to be a sub-shrine of Kamowake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) but some theories claim that the relocation of the main sanctuary in 1055 was the beginning of the shrine's rise to prominence.

It had long been considered to be a sub-shrine of Kamowake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) but some theories claim that the relocation of the main sanctuary in 1055 was the beginning of the shrine's rise to prominence.

It had long been considered to be a sub-shrine of Kamo Wake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) but some theories claim that the relocation of the main sanctuary in 1055 was the beginning of the shrine's rise to prominence.
sen.cmt: Kamo Wake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrineとしました。(参照: http://www.kamigamojinja.jp/english/index-e.html)

sen.j: 近世以降、それを不服として訴えが続けられ、明治以降になってようやく独立の神社となった。
sen.e: Objections to this rise had continued since the early modern period and the shrine finally became independent during after the Meiji era.
Objections to this rise had continued since the early modern period and the shrine finally became independent during after the Meiji era.
Objections to this rise had continued since the early modern period and the shrine finally became independent during after the Meiji period.

sen.j: 江戸時代までは賀茂別雷神社の祭神である賀茂別雷命も祭神としていた。
sen.e: The shrine also enshrined Kamowake Ikazuchino Mikoto, the enshrined deity of Kamowake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine, until the Edo period.
The shrine also enshrined Kamowake Ikazuchino Mikoto, the enshrined deity of Kamowake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine, until the Edo period.
The shrine also enshrined Kamo Wake Ikazuchi no Mikoto, the enshrined deity of Kamo Wake Ikazuchi-jinja Shrine, until the Edo period.
sen.cmt: Kamo Wake Ikazuchi no Mikotoとしました。

sen.j: 社殿は本宮・結社（中宮）・奥宮の3箇所に分かれて建っている。
sen.e: The main sanctuary is divided between the main shrine, middle shrine and rear shrine.
The main sanctuary is divided between the main shrine, middle shrine and rear shrine.
The main sanctuary is divided between the Motomiya (main shrine), Yui no yashiro or Nakamiya (middle shrine) and Okumiya (rear shrine).
sen.cmt: 後の内容から、本宮・結社（中宮）・奥宮の表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 本宮は高龗神を祭神とする。
sen.e: The main shrine enshrines Takaokami-no kami.
The main shrine enshrines Takaokami-no kami.
The Motomiya enshrines Takaokami no kami.
sen.cmt: main shrine→Motomiyaとし、ハイフンをとりTakaokami no kamiとしました。

sen.j: 本殿・拝殿は2007年に改築されたばかりである。
sen.e: The Honden (main hall) and Haiden (worship hall) were recently restored in 2007.
The Honden (main hall) and Haiden (worship hall) were recently restored in 2007.
The Honden (main hall) and Haiden (worship hall) were recently restored in 2007.

sen.j: 社務所等は本宮境内にある。
sen.e: The shrine office is located within the main shrine.
The shrine office is located within the main shrine.
The shrine office is located within the main shrine.

sen.j: 奥宮は本宮の上流側700メートルの場所にあり、以前はここが本宮であった。
sen.e: The rear shrine is located 700 meters upstream from the main shrine on what was previously the site of the main shrine.
The rear shrine is located 700 meters upstream from the main shrine on what was previously the site of the main shrine.
The Okumiya is located 700 meters upstream from the Motomiya on what was previously the site of the Motomiya.
sen.cmt: rear shrine→Okumiya, main shrine→Motomiyaとしました。

sen.j: 闇龗神（くらおかみのかみ）を祭神とするが、高龗神と同じ神であるとされている。
sen.e: It enshrines Kuraokami-no kami but is it is believed to be the same deity as Takaokami-no kami.
It enshrines Kuraokami-no kami but is it is believed to be the same deity as Takaokami-no kami.
It enshrines Kuraokami no kami but is it is believed to be the same deity as Takaokami no kami.
sen.cmt: Kuraokami no kami、 Takaokami no kamiとしました。

sen.j: 結社（ゆいのやしろ）は、本宮と奥宮の中間、本宮から上流側300メートルの場所にある。
sen.e: The middle shrine is located between the main shrine and rear shrine, approximately 300 meters upstream from the main shrine.
The middle shrine is located between the main shrine and rear shrine, approximately 300 meters upstream from the main shrine.
The Yui no Yashiro is located between the Motomiya and Okumiya, approximately 300 meters upstream from the Okumiya.
sen.cmt: middle shrine→Yui no Yashiro, main shrine→Motomiya, rear shrine→Okumiyaとしました。

sen.j: その立地から中宮（なかみや）とも呼ばれている。
sen.e: It is from this position that it gets the name "Nakamiya" (lit. middle shrine).
It is from this position that it gets the name "Nakamiya" (lit. middle shrine).
It is from this position that it gets the name "Nakamiya" (lit. middle shrine).

sen.j: イワナガヒメを祭神とし、縁結びの神として信仰される。
sen.e: It enshrines Iwanaga hime, who is worshipped as the god of marriage.
It enshrines Iwanaga hime, who is worshipped as the god of marriage.
It enshrines Iwanagahime, who is worshipped as the god of marriage.

sen.j: 磐長姫命が縁結びの神とされることになった理由として次のような伝承がある。
sen.e: The following legend describes how Iwanagahime-no Mikoto came to be regarded as the god of marriage.
The following legend describes how Iwanagahime-no Mikoto came to be regarded as the god of marriage.
The following legend describes how Iwanagahime no Mikoto came to be regarded as the god of marriage.
sen.cmt: Iwanagahime-no Mikotoのハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: 天孫ニニギが磐長姫命の妹のコノハナノサクヤビメと結婚しようとしたとき、姉妹の父のオオヤマツミは、磐長姫命も共に奉った。
sen.e: When Ninigi, grandson of Amaterasu, asked for permission to marry Konohana-no Sakuyabime, the daughter of Konohana-no Sakuyabime, her father, Oyamatsumi, granted him both her and her sister Iwanagahime-no Mikoto.

When Ninigi, grandson of Amaterasu, asked for permission to marry Konohana-no Sakuyabime, the daughter of Konohana-no Sakuyabime, her father, Oyamatsumi, granted him both her and her sister Iwanagahime-no Mikoto.

When Ninigi, grandson of Amaterasu, asked for permission to marry Konohana no Sakuyabime, the daughter of Konohana no Sakuyabime, her father, Oyamatsumi, granted him both her and her sister Iwanagahime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: Konohana-no Sakuyabime, Iwanagahime-no Mikotoのハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: しかし、瓊瓊杵尊は木花開耶姫とだけ結婚したので、磐長姫命はそれを恥じ、「縁結びの神として良縁を授けん」と言って当地に鎮まったという。
sen.e: However, Ninigi-no Mikoto married only Konohana-no Sakuhime, and the ashamed Iwanagahime-no Mikoto said "I will grant people their ideal match as the god of marriage" and was enshrined on the site of Kifune-jinja Shrine.

However, Ninigi-no Mikoto married only Konohana-no Sakuhime, and the ashamed Iwanagahime-no Mikoto said "I will grant people their ideal match as the god of marriage" and was enshrined on the site of Kifune-jinja Shrine.

However, Ninigi no Mikoto married only Konohana no Sakuyabime, and the ashamed Iwanagahime no Mikoto said 'I will grant people their ideal match as the god of marriage' and was enshrined on the site of Kifune-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、前出の表記に合わせ、Konohana-no Sakuhime→Konohana no Sakuyabimeとし、Ninigi-no Mikoto, Iwanagahime-no Mikotoのハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: 以前は、境内の細長い草の葉を結び合わせて縁結びを願っていたが、現在は植物保護のため本宮で授与される「結び文」に願文を書いて指定場所に結ぶことになっている。
sen.e: Previously, people would tie together the long thin blades of grass in the shrine precinct and pray for their ideal partner but plant protection measures have meant that people now write their prayer on a "Musubi-bumi" provided by the main shrine and tie it to a designated place.

Previously, people would tie together the long thin blades of grass in the shrine precinct and pray for their ideal partner but plant protection measures have meant that people now write their prayer on a "Musubi-bumi" provided by the main shrine and tie it to a designated place.

Previously, people would tie together the long thin blades of grass in the shrine precincts and pray for their ideal partner but plant protection measures have meant that people now write their prayer on a 'Musubi-bumi' provided by the main shrine and tie it to a designated place.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、 shrine precinctsとしました。

sen.j: 境内には、「磐長姫命の御料船」として平成8年に奉納された船形の自然石「天の磐船」が置かれている。
sen.e: A natural stone in the shape of a boat and known as "Ama-no-Iwabune" that was dedicated to the temple in 1996 as "Goryobune of Iwanagahime-no Mikoto" is placed in the precinct.
A natural stone in the shape of a boat and known as "Ama-no-Iwabune" that was dedicated to the temple in 1996 as "Goryobune of Iwanagahime-no Mikoto" is placed in the precinct.
A natural stone in the shape of a boat and known as 'Ama no Iwabune' that was dedicated to the temple in 1996 as 'Goryobune of Iwanagahime no Mikoto' is placed in the precincts.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、ハイフンを消去、precinct→precinctsに修正

sen.j: また、後述の和泉式部の歌碑がある。
sen.e: There is also a monument on which the poem by Shikibu IZUMI written below is inscribed.
There is also a monument on which the poem by Shikibu IZUMI written below is inscribed.
There is also a monument on which the poem by Izumi Shikibu written below is inscribed.

sen.j: 当社は古くから文芸にも多く登場している。
sen.e: Kifune-jinja Shrine has appeared in literature since ancient times.
Kifune-jinja Shrine has appeared in literature since ancient times.
Kifune-jinja Shrine has appeared in literature since ancient times.

sen.j: 和泉式部が貴船神社に参詣したときの歌が後拾遺和歌集に収録されている。
sen.e: A poem written by Shikibu IZUMI when he visited Kifune-jinja Shrine is included in 'Goshui Wakashu' (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poems).
sen.cmt: 後拾遺和歌集→Goshui Wakashu (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poetry)[www.k-gallery.net/cgi-bin/list_en.cgi?]
sen.e: A poem written by Shikibu IZUMI when he visited Kifune-jinja Shrine is included in 'Goshui Wakashu' (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poems).
A poem written by Izumi Shikibu when he visited Kifune-jinja Shrine is included in Goshui Wakashu (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poems).
sen.cmt: Shikibu IZUMI→Izumu Shikibuとしました。原文に合わせ、Goshui Wakashuのクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 「男（夫の藤原保昌）に忘れられている頃、貴船神社に参拝し、御手洗川に蛍が飛んでいるのを見て詠んだ歌」として「物おもへば沢の蛍も我が身より あくがれいづる魂（たま）かとぞみる」（恋しさに悩んでいたら、沢に飛ぶ蛍も私の体から抜け出した魂ではないかと見える）という歌である。
sen.e: When she was forgotten by her husband (FUJIWARA no Yasumasa), she visited Kifune-jinja Shrine where she watched the fireflies flying around Mitarashi-gawa River and composed a poem:'Mono omohebasawa no hotaru mowagami yoriakugare idurutama ka to zo miru(So lost in thought,even the fireflies in the valley,seem like my spirit,escaped from my body,and wandering about).

When she was forgotten by her husband (FUJIWARA no Yasumasa), she visited Kifune-jinja Shrine where she watched the fireflies flying around Mitarashi-gawa River and composed a poem:'Mono omohebasawa no hotaru mowagami yoriakugare idurutama ka to zo miru(So lost in thought,even the fireflies in the valley,seem like my spirit,escaped from my body,and wandering about).

When she was forgotten by her husband (FUJIWARA no Yasumasa), she visited Kifune-jinja Shrine where she watched the fireflies flying around the Mitarashi-gawa River and composed a poem:'Mono omohebasawa no hotaru mowagami yoriakugare idurutama ka to zo miru(So lost in thought,even the fireflies in the valley,seem like my spirit,escaped from my body,and wandering about).
sen.cmt: "Mitarashi-gawa River"→"the Mitarashi-gawa River"に変更しました。

sen.j: それに対して貴船明神が返したと伝えられる歌「奥山にたぎりておつる滝つ瀬の たまちる許（ばかり）物な思ひそ」（奥山にたぎり落ちる滝の水玉が飛び散るように、（魂が飛び散ってしまうほど）思い悩んではいけない）も後拾遺和歌集に収録されている。
sen.e: Also included in 'Goshui Wakashu' (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poems) is the poem with which Kifune Myojin kami is said to have replied to her:'Okuyama nitagirite otsurutakitsu se notama chiru bakarimono na omohiso'(Deep in the mountains,in the shallows of the waterfall,rushing down,the spirit-waterdrops shatter and splash,do not be so lost in thought).

Also included in 'Goshui Wakashu' (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poems) is the poem with which Kifune Myojin kami is said to have replied to her:'Okuyama nitagirite otsurutakitsu se notama chiru bakarimono na omohiso'(Deep in the mountains,in the shallows of the waterfall,rushing down,the spirit-waterdrops shatter and splash,do not be so lost in thought).

Also included in Goshui Wakashu is the poem with which Kifune Myojin kami is said to have replied to her:'Okuyama nitagirite otsurutakitsu se notama chiru bakarimono na omohiso'(Deep in the mountains,in the shallows of the waterfall,rushing down,the spirit-waterdrops shatter and splash,do not be so lost in thought).
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ、Goshui Wakashuのクォーテーションを削除し、補足は前出のため省きました。

sen.j: 後の時代に書かれた『沙石集』には、このときの参詣の様子が詳しく書かれている。
sen.e: The "Shasekishu" (Sand and Pebbles) collection of Buddhist parables gives a detailed description of the temple at this time.
The "Shasekishu" (Sand and Pebbles) collection of Buddhist parables gives a detailed description of the temple at this time.
The "Shasekishu" (Sand and Pebbles) collection of Buddhist parables gives a detailed description of the temple at this time.

sen.j: 和泉式部は巫女に縁結びの祭を行わせたが、その一環として巫女は、和泉式部の着物の裾をめくって陰部を露出させる作法をすることを迫った。
sen.e: Shikibu IZUMI had the shrine maiden conduct a matchmaking ceremony but the shrine maiden tried to force her to roll up the hem of her kimono and expose her genitalia
Shikibu IZUMI had the shrine maiden conduct a matchmaking ceremony but the shrine maiden tried to force her to roll up the hem of her kimono and expose her genitalia
Izumi Shikibu had the shrine maiden conduct a matchmaking ceremony but the shrine maiden tried to force her to roll up the hem of her kimono and expose her genitalia

sen.j: 和泉式部はそれを拒否したが、その様子を夫の保昌が神社の陰から見ており、その態度に感じ入ってその後は夫婦円満になったという。
sen.e: Shikibu IZUMI refused, but FUJIWARA no Yasumasa saw this from an unseen location within the shrine and was so impressed with her attitude that they became happily married.
Shikibu IZUMI refused, but FUJIWARA no Yasumasa saw this from an unseen location within the shrine and was so impressed with her attitude that they became happily married.
Izumi Shikibu refused, but FUJIWARA no Yasumasa saw this from an unseen location within the shrine and was so impressed with her attitude that they became happily married.

sen.j: 叡山電鉄叡山電鉄鞍馬線 貴船口駅
sen.e: Kifuneguchi Station on the Kurama Line of the Eizan Electric Railway.
Kifuneguchi Station on the Kurama Line of the Eizan Electric Railway.
Kibuneguchi Station on the Kurama Line of the Eizan Electric Railway.

sen.j: 春分の日から11月末日頃の日曜日までは、京都バスが貴船口駅から貴船集落の南の端にある貴船バス停留所まで運転される。
sen.e: From the Vernal Equinox Holiday to the last Sunday in November, Kyoto Bus operates a route from Kifuneguchi Station to the Kifune bus stop in the very south of the Kifune area.
From the Vernal Equinox Holiday to the last Sunday in November, Kyoto Bus operates a route from Kifuneguchi Station to the Kifune bus stop in the very south of the Kifune area.
From the Vernal Equinox Holiday to the last Sunday in November, Kyoto Bus operates a route from Kibuneguchi Station to the Kibune bus stop in the very south of the Kifune area.
sen.cmt: Kifuneguchi→Kibuneguchi, Kifune bus stop→Kibune bus stopに修正 (参照: http://www.kyotobus.jp/rosen/kibune/index.html)

sen.j: 所要4分、下車後徒歩5分。
sen.e: The bus journey takes 4 minutes followed by a 5 minute walk after alighting.
The bus journey takes 4 minutes followed by a 5 minute walk after alighting.
The bus journey takes four minutes followed by a five minute walk after alighting.

sen.j: それ以外の時期は駅から徒歩30分。
sen.e: This journey takes 30 minutes at other times of the year.
This journey takes 30 minutes at other times of the year.
This journey takes 30 minutes at other times of the year.

sen.j: 年始の初詣時期にもバスが運転される。
sen.e: A bus is also operated during the hatsumode (first shrine visit of the New Year) period at the beginning of the year.
A bus is also operated during the hatsumode (first shrine visit of the New Year) period at the beginning of the year.
A bus is also operated during the hatsumode (first shrine visit of the New Year) period at the beginning of the year.

sen.j: 源義経や弁慶の時代を堪能できる観光スポットとして、鞍馬寺とあわせて周遊するコースも人気が高い。
sen.e: Along with Kurama-dera Temple, Kifune-jinja Shrine is a popular excursion stop as a sightseeing spot which enables visitors to experience the time of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and Benkei.
Along with Kurama-dera Temple, Kifune-jinja Shrine is a popular excursion stop as a sightseeing spot which enables visitors to experience the time of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and Benkei.
Along with Kurama-dera Temple, Kifune-jinja Shrine is a popular excursion stop as a sightseeing spot which enables visitors to experience the time of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and Benkei.

sen.j: 鞍馬寺西門（貴船口）は貴船川に面しているが、 鞍馬寺の主要な諸堂までの参道は山道となっており、ハイキングの用意が必要である。
sen.e: Kurama-dera Temple's Nishimon (western gate) (Kifuneguchi) faces Kifune-gawa River but the mountain path to the temple's main halls means that visitors must be prepared to hike.
Kurama-dera Temple's Nishimon (western gate) (Kifuneguchi) faces Kifune-gawa River but the mountain path to the temple's main halls means that visitors must be prepared to hike.
Kurama-dera Temple's Nishimon (western gate) (Kibuneguchi) faces the Kifune-gawa River but the mountain path to the temple's main halls means that visitors must be prepared to hike.
sen.cmt: Kibuneguchiとしました。"Kifune-gawa River"→"the Kifune-gawa Rive"に変更しました。

sen.j: この場合鞍馬駅から鞍馬寺経由で貴船に向かうコースの方が主流である。
sen.e: In this case, the route from Kurama Station to Kifune via Kurama-dera Temple is more popular.
In this case, the route from Kurama Station to Kifune via Kurama-dera Temple is more popular.
In this case, the route from Kurama Station to Kifune via Kurama-dera Temple is more popular.

sen.j: 当社から勧請を受けた同名の貴船神社（貴布禰神社、木舟神社）が日本各地に約450社ある。
sen.e: There are approximately 450 shrines throughout Japan named 'Kifine-jinja Shrine' (including those written using alternative characters) which have received the divided tutelary deity of the head shrine in Sakyo Ward.

There are approximately 450 shrines throughout Japan named 'Kifine-jinja Shrine' (including those written using alternative characters) which have received the divided tutelary deity of the head shrine in Sakyo Ward.

There are approximately 450 shrines throughout Japan named 'Kifine-jinja Shrine' (including those written using alternative characters) which have received the divided tutelary deity of the head shrine in Sakyo Ward.

sen.j: また、祭神の「おかみ」を社名とする神社（高龗神社、龗神社、意賀美神社、闇龗神社など）は2000社を超える。
sen.e: Additionally, there are over 2000 shrines that incorporate the 'okami' of the enshrined deity's name into the shrine name (Takaokami-jinja Shrine, Okami-jinja Shrine, Okami-jinja Shrine, Kuraokami-jinja Shrine).

Additionally, there are over 2000 shrines that incorporate the 'okami' of the enshrined deity's name into the shrine name (Takaokami-jinja Shrine, Okami-jinja Shrine, Okami-jinja Shrine, Kuraokami-jinja Shrine).
Additionally, there are over 2000 shrines that incorporate the 'okami' of the enshrined deity's name into the shrine name (Takaokami-jinja Shrine, Okami-jinja Shrine, Kuraokami-jinja Shrine, etc.).
sen.cmt: "Okami-jinja Shrine"の表記が重複するため、片方を削除し、「など」を訳出しました。
